title: How to succeed in the field of sciences - Quora

response.answer_text: Contrary to what you might think science is not a fully functional meritocracy. Much depends on pure dumb luck and patronage. You can have all the right qualifications, work hard and do all the right things and your number might simply never come up. I would say that only a minority get their jobs via advertisement - application - shortlist- interview - appoint. Most get their jobs through internal advertisement and by nomination. It took me 25–30y to realise that. I felt a complete fool. I got my first real job when I was 60y old and it was by nomination. I was offered a job without asking and I took it. By the way do not believe stories about upcoming shortages of scientists. It is a cynical lie to keep up the supply of graduate students. For most, getting your masters or PhD is a termination of employment and a post-doc is merely a reprieve. It is all a Ponzi scheme. It is also a situation where your intelligence and rationality works against you - you cannot understand that your obvious ability and talent will not be recognised and rewarded. The rejection notice of the last open advertisement I even applied for (2010) proudly informed me they had 400 applicants.

I am in social science not exactly the natural sciences but this what I have learned from the professors and other researchers. Money matters. Research costs lot of money. More money, better lab, more likely to get results.Interact with other fields. You will find new ideas and someone in another field may have a methodology to solve your research problem.Be humble. Learn that we really don’t know much.Don’t burnout. New discoveries are hard. Take a long term view.Don’t take sides. Don’t get into politics in school or the field.Keep reading and studying. Don’t be lazy on your studying.Reputation matters. Be nice to everyone. Don’t screw anyone.

Read my book, The Seed of the Universe. I have some answers to a few things in science that they have wrong. Prove them right according to the Bible) and win the Nobel prize. That would be a nice start for you. I also have a pyramid of chemical elements that contains the atomic weight and number of every element. Find out what it is and you might win the Nbel prize another year. CompleteBook.docx

The same way as in practically any other field, but perhaps more so in science. By breaking hard, important problems into smaller, simpler ones that you can easily solve. Working under inspirationally smart mentors would also help.
Research, interact with other fields, and do not let your opinion lead you to take sides.
